conversation.content: [stunned] 马克？他们说要派最好的技术员过来，我...我真没想到6年没联系了，推开我工作室门的会是你。
[quietly] 嗯，那个...派单的时候也不会说客户名字，就给个地址和虫害类型。[exhales] 木偶工作室里有白蚁，这个我还真是头一回碰到。
你看起来不错。
谢谢，你也是，不过你头发里还是有木屑，跟以前一样，这让我觉得...唉，好像爸爸葬礼之后，有些东西还是没变。
[wistful] 这些提线木偶是爸留给我的全部了，你知道吧？每个关节都是他手把手教我刻的，现在白蚁在一点点啃食他留下的东西。
[gently] 先让我看看损坏程度，别急，好吗？有时候看着很严重的，其实发现得早，处理得当，还是能挽救的。
[bitter laugh] 呵，你什么时候变得这么乐观了？
自从我明白了...就是...不是什么都要毁掉才能解决问题，[sighs]，说真的，我花了太长时间才懂这个道理，想想我这些年断了多少后路啊。
[softer] 你这是在为遗嘱宣读那天说我职业选择的话道歉呢，还是我们继续装作那次争吵没发生过？
[measured] 我不该说你做木偶是浪费爸爸的工具和手艺，完全不该，这些年...大概每个星期都会想起那次吵架。[pause] 对不起，安娜。
[voice breaking] 天啊，马克，我生了你这么久的气，都忘了其实...其实是想念有个哥哥在身边是什么感觉。
[roughly] 这是干木白蚁，比地下白蚁扩散得慢，所以你的木偶...定点处理加上仔细修复，应该能救回来。[clears throat]
[grateful] 你在用技术话题转移注意力，跟爸爸情绪上来时一模一样，不过...谢谢你没有直接判死刑。
[warmly] 还记得吗？妈妈一哭，他就开始讲木纹的事。[chuckles] 家里闹矛盾呢，突然就变成橡木和松木的区别讲座了。
角落里那个，戴蓝帽子的小丑，是他确诊前雕的最后一块胡桃木。
我会救下它的，安娜，我保证，就算下班后要一寸一寸手工处理，有些东西...不管怎样都值得保存。[determined]
[hopeful] 等你处理完，能不能...留下来喝杯咖啡？我是说，如果你愿意的话，6年的生活，总得聊聊吧。
[relieved laugh] 咖啡太好了，说不定你还能教教我这些线是怎么操作的，我一直没搞明白你是怎么让它们看起来那么...那么有生命力的。
[tenderly] 其实就是要接受你和更大的整体相连，你的每个动作都会影响整场演出，这个道理...我觉得对家人也一样。
[quietly moved] 是啊，我现在终于开始明白了，爸爸要是知道我们能在他的工作室里，在他热爱的一切中间说这些话，应该会很欣慰吧。[soft exhale]

original_conversation.content: [stunned] Marcus? When they said they were sending their best technician, I never imagined it would be you walking through my workshop door after six years of silence.

[quietly] Yeah, well, dispatch doesn't exactly announce the client names when they assign jobs, just addresses and pest types. [exhales] Termites in a puppet workshop, that's definitely a first for me.
You look good.
Thanks, you too, though you've got sawdust in your hair like always, which honestly makes me feel like maybe not everything has changed since Dad's funeral.
[wistful] These marionettes are all I have left of him, you know? He taught me to carve each joint by hand, and now the termites are literally eating away at his legacy.
[gently] Let me take a look at the damage before we panic, alright? Sometimes what looks catastrophic is actually manageable if we catch it early enough and treat it properly.
[bitter laugh] Since when are you optimistic?
Since I learned that destroying everything in sight isn't always the answer, which took me longer than it should have, [sighs], considering how many bridges I burned along the way.
[softer] Is that your way of apologizing for what you said about my career choice at the reading of the will, or are we still pretending that conversation never happened?
[measured] I was wrong to call your puppets a waste of Dad's tools and talent, completely wrong, and I've thought about that fight probably every week since then. [pause] I'm sorry, Anna.
[voice breaking] God, Marcus, I've been so angry at you for so long that I forgot what it felt like to actually miss having my brother around.

[roughly] These termites are drywood species, which means they're slower-moving than subterranean types, so your puppets might be salvageable with targeted treatment and some careful restoration work. [clears throat]
[grateful] You're deflecting with technical talk just like Dad used to do when things got too emotional, but thank you for not just condemning everything to the trash.
[warmly] Remember how he'd start explaining wood grain patterns whenever Mom cried? [chuckles] We'd be having a family crisis and suddenly we're getting a lecture on oak versus pine.
The puppet in the corner, the jester with the blue hat, that's made from the last piece of walnut he ever worked with before the diagnosis.
I'll save it, Anna, I promise, even if I have to hand-treat every single inch myself after hours, because some things are worth preserving no matter what. [determined]
[hopeful] Maybe after you're done with the treatment, you could stay for coffee? I mean, we have six years of life to catch up on, if you're interested.
[relieved laugh] Coffee sounds perfect, and maybe you can finally teach me how these strings work, since I never understood how you made them look so alive and human.
[tenderly] It's all about accepting that you're connected to something bigger than yourself, that every movement you make affects the whole performance, which I guess applies to families too.
[quietly moved] Yeah, I'm starting to understand that now, finally, and I think Dad would be glad we're having this conversation in his workshop, surrounded by everything he loved. [soft exhale]

scenario: A puppeteer discovers their beloved marionette workshop has been infested with termites, forcing them to call the pest control technician who happens to be their estranged sibling.
